message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Detecting and Tracking Political Abuse in Social Media
Paper Abstract: We study astroturf political campaigns on microblogging platforms: politically-motivated individuals and organizations that use multiple centrally-controlled accounts to create the appearance of widespread support for a candidate or opinion. We describe a machine learning framework that combines topological, content-based and crowdsourced features of information diffusion networks on Twitter to detect the early stages of viral spreading of political misinformation. We present promising preliminary results with better than 96% accuracy in the detection of astroturf content in the run-up to the 2010 U.S. midterm elections.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, "Astroturf" refers to two main things:

## 1. AstroTurf (The Brand)
AstroTurf is an American subsidiary of SportGroup that produces artificial turf for playing surfaces in sports.(no content)The original AstroTurf product was a short-pile synthetic turf invented in 1965 by Monsanto.(no content)The material came to public prominence in 1966, when AstroTurf was installed in the Astrodome in Houston, Texas.

## 2. Astroturfing (The Political/Marketing Term)
Astroturfing is the use of fake grassroots efforts that primarily focus on influencing public opinion and typically are funded by corporations and political entities to form opinions.(no content)The modern usage of the term "astroturf" is widely credited to former Treasury Secretary of the United States and senator from Texas Lloyd Bentsen who, in 1985, when faced with a barrage of postcards and letters facilitated by insurance companies claiming to be concerned constituents, said that "a fellow from Texas can tell the difference between grass roots and Astroturf".(no content)On the internet, "astroturfers" use software to hide their identity.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about microblogging:

## What is Microblogging?

Microblogging is a form of blogging using short posts without titles known as microposts or status updates.(no content)Microblogs allow users to exchange small elements of content such as short sentences, individual images, or video links.

## Notable Microblogging Services

Among the most notable services are Twitter, Tumblr, Mastodon, Micro.blog, FriendFeed, Plurk, Jaiku and identi.ca.(no content)Facebook, MySpace, LinkedIn, Diaspora, JudgIt and XING also have their own microblogging feature, better known as "status updates".

## Characteristics

Microblogging posts typically follow a short format. Posts usually contain 280 characters or less.

## Microblogging in China

In China, microblogging goes by a different name. Weibo is a general term for microblogging, normally understood as Chinese-based mini-blogging services that make it possible for internet users to set up real-time information sharing communities and upload and update information.

Here's what I found about Twitter:

## Overview

X, formerly known as Twitter, is an American microblogging and social networking service.(no content)It is one of the world's largest social media platforms and one of the most-visited websites.

## Origins and Early History

Work on the project started in February 2006. The first Twitter prototype, developed by Dorsey and contractor Florian Weber, was used as an internal service for Odeo employees. The full version was introduced publicly on July 15, 2006.(no content)The tipping point for Twitter's popularity was the 2007 South by Southwest Interactive (SXSWi) conference. During the event, Twitter usage increased from 20,000 tweets per day to 60,000.

## Elon Musk Acquisition and Rebranding

The service is owned by the American company X Corp., which was established to succeed the prior owner Twitter, Inc. in March 2023 following the October 2022 acquisition of Twitter by Elon Musk for US$44 billion.(no content)In July 2023, Musk announced that Twitter would be rebranded to "X" and the bird logo would be retired, a process which was completed by May 2024.

## Recent Developments

In March 2025, X Corp. was acquired by xAI, Musk's artificial intelligence company. The deal, an all-stock transaction, valued X at $33 billion, with a full valuation of $45 billion when factoring in $12 billion in debt.

Links: [{"title":"Twitter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter"},{"title":"Twitter, Inc. - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter,_Inc."},{"title":"Twitter under Elon Musk - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter_under_Elon_Musk"},{"title":"Twitter Files - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter_Files"},{"title":"Censorship of Twitter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Censorship_of_Twitter"},{"title":"Stan Twitter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stan_Twitter"},{"title":"History of Twitter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Twitter"},{"title":"Acquisition of Twitter by Elon Musk - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acquisition_of_Twitter_by_Elon_Musk"},{"title":"2020 Twitter account hijacking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Twitter_account_hijacking"},{"title":"Twitter verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter_verification"}]

Here's what I found about Twitter:

## Overview

X, formerly known as Twitter, is an American microblogging and social networking service.(no content)It is one of the world's largest social media platforms and one of the most-visited websites.

## Origins and Early History

Work on the project started in February 2006. The first Twitter prototype, developed by Dorsey and contractor Florian Weber, was used as an internal service for Odeo employees. The full version was introduced publicly on July 15, 2006.(no content)The tipping point for Twitter's popularity was the 2007 South by Southwest Interactive (SXSWi) conference. During the event, Twitter usage increased from 20,000 tweets per day to 60,000.

## Elon Musk Acquisition and Rebranding

The service is owned by the American company X Corp., which was established to succeed the prior owner Twitter, Inc. in March 2023 following the October 2022 acquisition of Twitter by Elon Musk for US$44 billion.(no content)In July 2023, Musk announced that Twitter would be rebranded to "X" and the bird logo would be retired, a process which was completed by May 2024.

## Recent Developments

In March 2025, X Corp. was acquired by xAI, Musk's artificial intelligence company. The deal, an all-stock transaction, valued X at $33 billion, with a full valuation of $45 billion when factoring in $12 billion in debt.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Information diffusion"

Links: [{"title":"Diffusion of innovations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diffusion_of_innovations"},{"title":"Sociological theory of diffusion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sociological_theory_of_diffusion"},{"title":"Information cascade - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_cascade"},{"title":"Diffusion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diffusion"},{"title":"Confusion and diffusion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Confusion_and_diffusion"},{"title":"Alex Bavelas - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alex_Bavelas"},{"title":"Diffusion (business) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diffusion_(business)"},{"title":"Diffusion process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diffusion_process"},{"title":"Everett Rogers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Everett_Rogers"},{"title":"Stable Diffusion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stable_Diffusion"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about information diffusion:

## Overview

Diffusion of innovations is a theory that seeks to explain how, why, and at what rate new ideas and technology spread.(no content)The theory was popularized by Everett Rogers in his book Diffusion of Innovations, first published in 1962.

## Core Definition

Rogers argues that diffusion is the process by which an innovation is communicated through certain channels over time among the participants in a social system.

## Key Elements

Rogers proposes that five main elements influence the spread of a new idea: the innovation itself, adopters, communication channels, time, and a social system.

## Types of Diffusion

Diffusion of information and ideas has been categorized into two modes: Internal diffusion is the spread of information and innovations within a network, flowing within a single adopting population – a given industry or geographical network.

## Categories of Adopters

Rogers proposes that adopters of any new innovation or idea can be categorized as innovators (2.5%), early adopters (13.5%), early majority (34%), late majority (34%) and laggards (16%), based on the mathematically based Bell curve.

## Network Factors

Not all individuals exert an equal amount of influence over others. In this sense opinion leaders are influential in spreading either positive or negative information about an innovation.

Web search results for query: "Misinformation"

Links: [{"title":"Misinformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation"},{"title":"COVID-19 misinformation by governments - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_misinformation_by_governments"},{"title":"COVID-19 misinformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_misinformation"},{"title":"Misinformation in the Gaza war - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation_in_the_Gaza_war"},{"title":"Vaccine misinformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vaccine_misinformation"},{"title":"COVID-19 misinformation by China - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_misinformation_by_China"},{"title":"5G misinformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/5G_misinformation"},{"title":"Misinformation about violence by transgender people - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation_about_violence_by_transgender_people"},{"title":"Misinformation about the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation_about_the_2024_Atlantic_hurricane_season"},{"title":"Seed oil misinformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seed_oil_misinformation"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about misinformation:

## Definition and Distinction

Misinformation is incorrect or misleading information.(no content)Whereas misinformation can exist with or without specific malicious intent, disinformation is deliberately deceptive and intentionally propagated.(no content)Misinformation is typically spread unintentionally, mostly caused by a lack of knowledge, an error, or simply a misunderstanding, which contrasts with disinformation.

## Types of Misinformation

Misinformation can include inaccurate, incomplete, misleading, or false information as well as selective or half-truths.

## Spread and Impact

Social media platforms, such as Facebook, Instagram, X, etc., are designed in ways that enable information, including misinformation, to be posted and shared far more quickly than through other communication mediums.(no content)Misinformation can influence people's beliefs about communities, politics, medicine, and more.

## Global Concern

In January 2024, the World Economic Forum identified misinformation and disinformation, propagated by both internal and external interests, to "widen societal and political divides" as the most severe global risks in the short term.

## Susceptibility Factors

Research shows that several factors, including cognitive biases, emotional responses, social dynamics, and media literacy levels, can influence susceptibility to misinformation.

Here are the search results for "Machine learning":

## Overview

Machine learning (ML) is a field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalise to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions.

## Applications

ML finds application in many fields, including natural language processing, computer vision, speech recognition, email filtering, agriculture, and medicine.

## Main Learning Paradigms

Machine learning is commonly separated into three main learning paradigms, supervised learning, unsupervised learning and reinforcement learning.

## Historical Development

The term machine learning was coined in 1959 by Arthur Samuel, an IBM employee and pioneer in the field of computer gaming and artificial intelligence. The field has evolved significantly, with advances in the field of deep learning allowing neural networks, a class of statistical algorithms, to surpass many previous machine learning approaches in performance.

The search results include information about neural networks, attention mechanisms, computational learning theory, and various ML architectures and techniques that have contributed to the field's development.

## Political Campaign - Search Results

I've completed the web search for "Political campaign." Here's a summary of what I found:

### Definition and Purpose

A political campaign is an organized effort which seeks to influence the decision making progress within a specific group.(no content)In democracies, political campaigns often refer to electoral campaigns, by which representatives are chosen or referendums are decided.

### Key Components

**Campaign Messages:** The message of the campaign contains the ideas that the candidate wants to share with the voters, designed to get those who agree with their ideas to support them when running for a political position.

**Campaign Organization:** In a modern political campaign, the campaign organization will have a coherent structure of personnel consisting of a group of paid employees and unpaid volunteers, with campaigns run by campaign managers, political consultants, and activist or volunteers.

### Campaign Advertising

In politics, campaign advertising is propaganda through the media to influence a political debate and, ultimately, voting.(no content)The period over which political campaign advertising is possible varies significantly from country to country, with campaigns in the United States lasting a year or more to places like the UK and Ireland, where advertising is restricted by law to just a short period of weeks before the election.

### Campaign Finance

The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is the primary United States federal law regulating political campaign fundraising and spending.

The search results cover various aspects of political campaigns including their structure, messaging strategies, advertising methods, and legal frameworks governing them.

Web search results for query: "2010 United States midterm elections"

Links: [{"title":"2010 United States elections - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_United_States_elections"},{"title":"2010 United States House of Representatives elections - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections"},{"title":"2010 United States Senate elections - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_United_States_Senate_elections"},{"title":"2010 United States state legislative elections - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_United_States_state_legislative_elections"},{"title":"United States midterm election - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_midterm_election"},{"title":"2010s in United States history - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010s_in_United_States_political_history"},{"title":"2010 United States gubernatorial elections - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_United_States_gubernatorial_elections"},{"title":"Midterm election - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mid-term_elections"},{"title":"2010 United States Senate election in Pennsylvania - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_United_States_Senate_election_in_Pennsylvania"},{"title":"2012 United States House of Representatives elections - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of the 2010 United States midterm elections:

## Overview

Elections were held in the United States on November 2, 2010, in the middle of Democratic President Barack Obama's first term.(no content)Approximately 82.5 million people voted.

## Major Results

Republicans ended unified Democratic control of Congress and the presidency by winning a majority in the House of Representatives and gained seats in the Senate despite Democrats holding Senate control.

**House of Representatives:** Republicans won the nationwide popular vote for the House of Representatives by a margin of 6.8 points and picked up 63 seats, taking control of the chamber for the first time since the 2006 elections.(no content)This represented the largest single-election shift in House seats since the 1948 elections and the largest midterm election shift since the 1938 elections.

**Senate:** Republicans gained seven seats in the Senate (including a special election held in January 2010) but failed to gain a majority in the chamber.

**State Elections:** In state elections, Republicans won a net gain of six gubernatorial seats and flipped control of twenty state legislative chambers, giving them a substantial advantage in the redistricting that occurred following the 2010 United States census.

## Characterization

The election was widely characterized as a "Republican wave" election, and President Obama called it "a shellacking."

## Key Factors

At the time of the election, unemployment was over 9%, and had not declined significantly since Barack Obama had become president.(no content)The heavy Democratic Party losses in 2010 were attributed to anger at President Obama, opposition to the Affordable Care Act and American Recovery and Reinvestment Act, large budget deficits, and the weak economy.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! All tasks completed successfully. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

I've successfully extracted and classified the key technologies and methodologies from the paper "Detecting and Tracking Political Abuse in Social Media":

**Paper Classification:** Contribution (proposes a machine learning framework)

**Key Entities Identified (8 triples):**

1. **Astroturfing** (concept, uses) - The paper studies centrally-controlled account networks designed to create false grassroots support
2. **Political campaign** (task, uses) - Focus on detecting politically-motivated campaigns during elections
3. **Microblogging** (tool, uses) - The research analyzes campaigns on microblogging platforms
4. **Twitter** (tool, uses) - The specific platform studied for detecting viral spreading patterns
5. **Machine learning** (method, uses) - Framework combining topological, content-based, and crowdsourced features
6. **Diffusion of innovations** (concept, proposes) - Framework analyzes information diffusion networks for detection
7. **Misinformation** (task, proposes) - Proposes a framework to detect viral spreading of political misinformation
8. **2010 United States elections** (data, uses) - Dataset from the 2010 U.S. midterm elections

**Validation Result:** ✅ All checks passed successfully with all Wikipedia URLs verified.

Sources:
- [Astroturfing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astroturfing)
- [Political campaign](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_campaign)
- [Microblogging](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microblogging)
- [Twitter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter)
- [Machine learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning)
- [Diffusion of innovations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diffusion_of_innovations)
- [Misinformation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation)
- [2010 United States elections](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_United_States_elections)
